source: 404 (or Not Found) error message is an HTTP standard response code indicating that the client was able to communicate with a given server, but the server could not find what was requested. Please install the Redirect 404 submodule to be able to log all paths that have resulted in 404 errors.

"Fix 404 pages" lists all paths that have resulted in 404 errors and do not yet have any redirects assigned to them. This 404 (or Not Found) error message is an HTTP standard response code indicating that the client was able to communicate with a given server, but the server could not find what was requested.
A redirect set for a specific language will always be used when requesting this page in that language, and takes precedence over redirects set for All languages.
Add URL redirect from this page to another location
Allows users to redirect between domains.
Allows users to redirect from old URLs to new URLs.
An error occurred while processing @operation with arguments : @args
Are you sure you want to delete the URL redirect from %source to %redirect?
Are you sure you want to delete this redirect?
Automatically create redirects when URL aliases are changed.
Check access to the redirected page
Delete all URL redirects before generating new URL redirects.
Display a warning message to users when they are redirected.

Enabling this will automatically redirect to the canonical URL of any page. That includes redirecting to an alias if existing, removing trailing slashes, ensure the language prefix is set and similar clean-up.
Enter an internal Drupal path or path alias to redirect (e.g. %example1 or %example2). Fragment anchors (e.g. %anchor) are not allowed.

For example, given a redirect from %source to %redirect, if a user visits %sourcequery they would be redirected to %redirectquery. The query strings in the redirection will always take precedence over the current query string.
How many URL redirects would you like to generate?
It is not allowed to create a redirect from the front page.
Link data valid for redirect source link type.
Lists 404 error paths with no redirect assigned yet.
Logs 404 errors and allows users to create redirects for often requested but missing pages.
No protocol should be included in the redirect domain.
Note: links open in the current window.
Overview for 404 error paths with no redirect assigned yet.
Prevents logging 'page not found' events. Can be safely enabled when redirect_404 module is used, which stores them separately, nothing else relies on those messages.
Provide operation buttons to handle the 404 path.
Redirect is accessed from three tabs that help you manage URL Redirects.
Redirect loop identified at %path for redirect %rid
Redirect users from one URL to another.
Resolved the path %path in the database. Please check the ignored list and save the settings.
Specify pages by using their paths. Enter one path per line. The '*' character is a wildcard. An example path is %user-wildcard for every user page. %front is the front page.

The "URL Redirects" page is used to setup and manage URL Redirects. New redirects are created here using the Add redirect button which presents a form to simplify the creation of redirects . The URL redirects page provides a list of all redirects on the site and allows you to edit them.
The "Settings" page presents you with a number of means to adjust redirect settings.
The Redirect domain module allows users to redirect between domains.
The Redirect module allows users to redirect from old URLs to new URLs. For more information, see the online documentation for Redirect.
The anchor fragments are not allowed.
The base source path %source is already being redirected. Do you want to edit the existing redirect?
The date when the redirect was created.

The domain redirect is accessed through Domain Redirects. The user can add the domain redirects through the domain redirect table which consists of the domain from which it needs to be redirected, the sub path and the complete url destination to which it needs to be redirected. The module also supports the usage of a wildcard redirecting, thus many requests can be handled with one instance of domain redirect.
The domain redirect table consists of the domain from which it needs to be redirected, the sub path and the complete url destination to which it needs to be redirected.
The domain redirects have been saved.

The maximum number of 404 error logs to keep in the database log. Requires a cron maintenance task.
The number of requests with that path and language in a day.
The number of requests with that path and language.
The source path %path is likely a valid path. It is preferred to create URL aliases for existing paths rather than redirects.
The source path %source is already being redirected. Do you want to edit the existing redirect?
The timestamp of the last request with that path and language.
The url to redirect from should not start with a forward slash (/).
The user ID of the node author.
There are no 404 errors to fix.
This helps to stop redirection on protected pages and avoids giving away secret URL's. By default this feature is disabled to avoid any unexpected behavior
Top-down precedence is used. This means the first matching redirect that is found will be taken. For example, assume these redirect rules:
Whether or not this path has a redirect assigned.
Whether to log 'page not found' messages to the standard log or not.
You are attempting to redirect the page to itself. This will result in an infinite loop.
You can find more information about HTTP redirect status codes at @status-codes.
